data.title: A Look At Willdan Group (WLDN) Valuation After Record Results And New US$49 Million Energy Contract
data.description:
Willdan Group (WLDN) is back in focus after reporting higher fourth quarter and full year revenue and net income, alongside a new US$49 million energy services contract with Mt. San Antonio College in California.

See our latest analysis for Willdan Group.

Despite the strong contract wins and record financial results, Willdan Group’s share price has seen a sharp pullback recently, with a 1 day share price return of negative 25.47% and a 30 day share price return of negative 29.37%. At the same time, the 1 year total shareholder return sits at 172.60%, which points to fading short term momentum after a very strong multi year run.

If this volatility has you thinking about where else growth and infrastructure themes might show up in your portfolio, you can scan our 23 power grid technology and infrastructure stocks for other grid focused names that may be worth a closer look.

With the share price pulling back after record results, yet still sitting on a very large 1 year total return and trading below some analyst targets, you have to ask: is Willdan now undervalued, or is the market already pricing in future growth?

Advertisement

Most Popular Narrative: 38.5% Undervalued

With Willdan Group last closing at $89.14 against a narrative fair value of $145, the current share price sits well below that central estimate, setting up a clear gap between market pricing and this widely followed view.

Long term and increasing utility and municipal contracts, typically 3 to 5 years in duration and funded through stable sources, are contributing to recurring revenue and improved earnings visibility, reducing earnings volatility and supporting higher net margins.

Ongoing investments and planning for grid modernization, combined with the company's strong reputation with utility commissions and government agencies, position Willdan to benefit disproportionately from federal/state decarbonization mandates and infrastructure modernization initiatives, supporting sustained revenue and EBITDA growth over the long term.

Read the complete narrative.

Curious what has to happen for that higher fair value to stack up? The narrative leans on rising earnings power, thicker margins, and a future profit multiple that assumes Willdan keeps winning and scaling complex energy projects. The exact mix of revenue growth, profitability and required return might surprise you.

Result: Fair Value of $145 (UNDERVALUED)

Another Angle: Earnings Multiple Paints A Tougher Picture

While the SWS DCF model and analyst narrative suggest Willdan Group looks undervalued, the P/E ratio tells a more cautious story. At around 25x earnings versus 16.2x for peers and 20.2x for the broader US Professional Services industry, the stock is not cheap on this yardstick. How comfortable are you paying that premium?

data.title: Assessing Hokkaido Electric Power Company’s Valuation As Ishikariwan Shinko Expansion Plans Advance
data.description:
Hokkaido Electric Power Company (TSE:9509) plans higher output and an earlier build schedule at its Ishikariwan Shinko LNG plant, moves that put its generation mix and supply reliability in sharper focus for shareholders.

See our latest analysis for Hokkaido Electric Power Company.

The Ishikariwan Shinko update comes as momentum has been firming, with a 19.06% 1 month share price return, 11.86% year to date, and a 72.38% 1 year total shareholder return suggesting investors are reassessing both growth prospects and risk.

If you are looking beyond utilities for what else is moving, our screener of 23 power grid technology and infrastructure stocks is a useful way to spot other electricity and grid related names catching attention.

With the shares up sharply over 1 year and trading at a small discount to the ¥1,340 analyst target, the key question is whether Hokkaido Electric still offers value or if the market is already pricing in future growth.

Advertisement

Preferred P/E of 4.4x: Is it justified?

On a P/E of 4.4x and a last close of ¥1,230.5, Hokkaido Electric trades slightly above its peer average but well below both the broader JP market and its own estimated fair ratio.

The P/E multiple compares the current share price to earnings per share. For a utility like Hokkaido Electric it reflects what investors are willing to pay for each unit of earnings given its regulated returns, capital intensity and cash flow profile.

Here, the stock is described as expensive versus its immediate peer average P/E of 4.2x. It is also framed as good value against the Asian Electric Utilities average of 17.6x and a fair P/E estimate of 9.5x, suggesting the market is pricing its earnings materially lower than the level that model implies it could move towards.

Relative to the broader JP market P/E of 15.6x, the 4.4x P/E is also much lower, which again underlines how compressed the multiple looks compared with both domestic equities and the sector wide context.

Explore the SWS fair ratio for Hokkaido Electric Power Company

Result: Price-to-Earnings of 4.4x (UNDERVALUED)

However, you still need to weigh regulatory changes or project delays at Ishikariwan Shinko that could affect earnings, cash flows, and how reliable that P/E looks.

Find out about the key risks to this Hokkaido Electric Power Company narrative.

Another view: DCF points the other way

While the 4.4x P/E suggests room to move closer to the 9.5x fair ratio, our DCF model is more conservative. On that approach, Hokkaido Electric at ¥1,230.5 is trading above an estimated future cash flow value of ¥870.28, which implies limited upside and some valuation risk. Leadership change as a fresh lens on Aisin stock

Aisin (TSE:7259) is back in focus after its Board of Directors decided to change the company’s representative directors, putting a leadership transition at the center of the investment story.

From April 1, 2026, Yoshihisa Yamamoto is set to become Executive Vice President and Representative Director, while Shintaro Ito plans to retire from senior executive roles and be proposed as an Audit & Supervisory Board Member at the June 2026 shareholders’ meeting.

The leadership reshuffle comes after a mixed price backdrop, with the 1 day share price return of 2.39% and 7 day return of 3.64% sitting against a year to date share price decline of 7.47%. If this leadership news has you thinking more broadly about where growth could come from in mobility and manufacturing, it might be worth scanning 30 robotics and automation stocks as a fresh set of ideas to review next.

With Aisin trading at ¥2,779.5 and sitting at an estimated 45% discount to one intrinsic value measure and around 9% below the average analyst price target, is there still a buying opportunity here, or is the market already pricing in future growth?

Preferred P/E of 12.2x: Is it justified?

Aisin's current P/E of 12.2x sits at an interesting crossroads, with the shares at ¥2,779.5 and various signals pointing in different directions compared with both peers and an internally estimated fair ratio.

The P/E multiple compares the company’s share price with its earnings per share, so it essentially reflects what investors are currently willing to pay for each unit of profit. For an auto components group like Aisin, this is a common yardstick because earnings are a direct link to its large base of recurring supply contracts and exposure to vehicle production volumes.

Here, the picture is mixed. On one hand, Aisin is described as expensive versus the broader JP Auto Components industry average P/E of 11.4x, which suggests the market is paying a premium relative to many sector peers. On the other hand, the same 12.2x P/E is assessed as good value compared with an estimated fair P/E of 15.5x, as well as against a peer average of 19.3x in a separate comparison. Those reference points imply that if valuations shifted closer to the higher peer averages or the fair ratio, the multiple could move up from current levels rather than down.

data.title: A Look At Tokyu Fudosan Holdings (TSE:3289) Valuation After New ¥10b Green Bond Issuance
data.description:
Tokyu Fudosan Holdings (TSE:3289) has drawn fresh attention after completing a ¥10 billion unsecured green bond offering, featuring a 1.904% fixed coupon due March 12, 2031, following several climate focused issuances.

See our latest analysis for Tokyu Fudosan Holdings.

The green bond issuance comes as Tokyu Fudosan Holdings’ share price sits at ¥1,570.5, with a 30 day share price return of 11.42% and a 1 year total shareholder return of 67.00%, pointing to momentum that has built over time rather than overnight.

If this sustainable finance move has you thinking about where else long term themes could play out, it may be worth checking our screener of 23 power grid technology and infrastructure stocks as another way to look for potential ideas.

With annual revenue of ¥1,219,274 million and net income of ¥92,302 million, but a value score of 3 and the share price sitting slightly above analyst targets, investors may wonder whether there is still an attractive entry point or if the market is already pricing in future growth.

Advertisement

Preferred P/E of 12.1x: Is it justified?

Tokyu Fudosan Holdings trades on a P/E of 12.1x, while our data suggests a fair P/E closer to 16.2x. This points to a discount at the current ¥1,570.5 share price.

The P/E ratio compares the current share price with earnings per share, so it effectively tells you how much investors are paying for each unit of earnings. For a real estate group that is already profitable and generating net income of ¥92,302 million, P/E is a straightforward way to gauge how the market is pricing those earnings today.

Here, the company screens as good value against several yardsticks. The current 12.1x P/E is below the estimated fair P/E of 16.2x. It also sits below the peer average of 14.3x, the Japan real estate industry average of 12.8x, and the broader Japan market at 15.6x. That combination suggests the market is pricing Tokyu Fudosan Holdings at a lower earnings multiple than these reference points, while our fair ratio work points to a level the market could move towards if perceptions of its earnings strength and growth potential align with those benchmarks.

Explore the SWS fair ratio for Tokyu Fudosan Holdings

Result: Price-to-earnings of 12.1x (UNDERVALUED)

However, you are still relying on analyst estimates for that fair P/E, and on earnings that tie closely to real estate and energy markets, which can be cyclical.
